Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Common Problem Pedagogy Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The economic prosperity of the United States relies on progress in science, the advancement of national health initiatives, and overall national prosperity in an increasingly technical economy. This prosperity relies on a talented workforce with the ability to nimbly address new challenges and develop innovative technologies. The Common Problem Pedagogy project seeks to improve STEM teaching and learning through the integration of cross-disciplinary experiences and applied learning opportunities in ways that will strengthen STEM workforce preparation and produce a more STEM-literate public. STEM faculty will partner with one or more colleagues from the arts and humanities to identify a community partner with a significant problem or issue relevant to their disciplines. Each faculty member will incorporate problem-based learning activities in their courses to address the problem. Interdisciplinary teams of students from their classes will work together, applying the perspectives and tools of inquiry from their respective disciplines, to develop potential solutions that will be presented to the community partner at the end of the semester.

This project will be implemented on four SUNY Campuses: Cortland, Oneonta, Oswego, and Plattsburgh. The goals of the project are to demonstrate the effectiveness of Common Problem Pedagogy on student learning within STEM disciplines, to increase the number of STEM instructors proficient in this pedagogy, and to identify strategies for scaling up this methodology for large-scale adoption across the SUNY system and beyond. Thirty-two faculty members from the four campuses will participate in professional development opportunities to learn about the new pedagogy, implement it in their classes, and then evaluate the impact of this approach on the achievement of student learning outcomes related to problem-solving using interdisciplinary approaches. A train-the-trainer model will be adopted, whereby participating faculty members recruit additional faculty members to participate in future semesters. The principal investigators will gather data from participating faculty and community partners to identify challenges associated with implementing this method, and to evaluate students' success in working with community partners in cross-disciplinary teams to address meaningful, real-world problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Faculty members from four SUNY campuses (Cortland, Oneonta, Oswego and Plattsburgh) developed and tested a cross-disciplinary problem-based teaching method called Common Problem Pedagogy (CP2). At SUNY Cortland, 12 faculty members taught 16 courses using this methodology to over 200 students between spring 2018 and spring 2020. Faculty from STEM fields worked with colleagues from the arts, humanities or social sciences to identify a complex, ill-structured problem of common interest. Students from their respective classes worked in teams to develop proposed solutions to these problems.  Class projects have focused on a wide range of issues, including communicating the results of scientific research on topics ranging from water quality to the COVID-19 pandemic, conducting a biodiversity analysis of trees in a local village, developing strategies for providing marginalized populations with increased access to healthy, locally-sourced food, and promoting ecotourism in the Adirondacks. Some projects culminated with student presentations of their results to stakeholders from the local community. Those community partners have reported that they found value in the solutions proposed by the student teams.

 

Faculty have found CP2 to be effective in achieving course learning outcomes and promoting high levels of student engagement. Survey results indicate that a significant number of participating faculty intend to continue using this methodology. Some have also published or made conference presentations on their projects. Students identified several benefits, including opportunities to apply their learning in real world settings, the value of multiple perspectives in developing proposed solutions, and the development of important workforce skills including collaboration and communication across disciplinary boundaries. Assessment data indicates that students demonstrated improvement in their abilities to describe a complex problem, organize their approaches to developing solutions, evaluate their progress and adapt their solution methods, and integrate concepts and skills from multiple sources. Principal investigators from the four participating SUNY campuses have shared this project through presentations at national conferences and workshops, and through a video at the 2019 Stem for All event sponsored by the NSF. A manuscript co-authored by the PI's describing the CP2 methodology in detail was recently completed and has been submitted for peer review.
